IPO.name: Initial Public Offering
IPO.definition: The process by which a private company offers shares to the public for the first time
IPO.example: When a company 'goes public', it conducts an IPO to raise capital from public investors

P/E Ratio.name: Price-to-Earnings Ratio
P/E Ratio.definition: A valuation metric that compares a company's stock price to its earnings per share
P/E Ratio.formula: P/E = Stock Price / Earnings Per Share
P/E Ratio.interpretation: Higher P/E may indicate overvaluation or high growth expectations. Lower P/E may indicate undervaluation or low growth

EPS.name: Earnings Per Share
EPS.definition: A company's net profit divided by the number of outstanding shares
EPS.importance: Key indicator of company profitability on a per-share basis

Market Cap.name: Market Capitalization
Market Cap.definition: Total market value of a company's outstanding shares
Market Cap.formula: Market Cap = Share Price × Outstanding Shares

ROE.name: Return on Equity
ROE.definition: Measure of profitability that shows how much profit a company generates with shareholders' equity
ROE.interpretation: Higher ROE indicates better efficiency in generating returns

Dividend Yield.name: Dividend Yield
Dividend Yield.definition: Annual dividend payment as a percentage of stock price
Dividend Yield.formula: Dividend Yield = Annual Dividend per Share / Stock Price × 100%
Dividend Yield.interpretation: Higher yield may indicate good income investment, but verify sustainability

Beta.name: Beta Coefficient
Beta.definition: Measure of a stock's volatility compared to the overall market

EBITDA.name: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization
EBITDA.formula: EBITDA = Revenue - Operating Expenses (excluding interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization)
EBITDA.use_case: Compare profitability between companies and industries

RSI.name: Relative Strength Index
RSI.definition: Momentum indicator measuring speed and magnitude of price changes

MACD.name: Moving Average Convergence Divergence
MACD.definition: Trend-following momentum indicator showing relationship between two moving averages

S&P 500.name: Standard & Poor's 500
S&P 500.description: Stock market index tracking 500 largest U.S. publicly traded companies

NASDAQ.name: NASDAQ Composite
NASDAQ.description: Index of all stocks listed on NASDAQ exchange, heavy in technology

Dow Jones.name: Dow Jones Industrial Average
Dow Jones.description: Price-weighted index of 30 prominent U.S. companies

VIX.name: Volatility Index
VIX.description: Measure of market's expectation of 30-day volatility

Value Investing.description: Strategy of selecting stocks trading below their intrinsic value
Value Investing.approach: Buy undervalued stocks with strong fundamentals and hold long-term

Growth Investing.description: Investing in companies expected to grow at above-average rate
Growth Investing.characteristics: Higher P/E ratios, reinvest earnings, focus on future potential

Dividend Investing.description: Focus on stocks that pay regular, sustainable dividends
Dividend Investing.target_companies: Mature, profitable companies with stable cash flows

Momentum Trading.description: Strategy based on continuing trends in stock prices

Technology.description: Companies producing software, hardware, semiconductors, and IT services

Healthcare.description: Pharmaceuticals, biotech, medical devices, healthcare services
Healthcare.characteristics: Defensive sector, driven by demographics and innovation

Financials.characteristics: Interest rate sensitive, economic cycle dependent

Consumer Discretionary.characteristics: Economic cycle sensitive, driven by consumer confidence

warnings: Unprofitable with no clear path to profitability

Diversification.principle: Don't put all eggs in one basket
strategies: Mix of growth and value stocks

Position Sizing.guideline: Limit single position to 5-10% of portfolio
Position Sizing.rationale: Minimize impact of individual stock failures

Stop Loss.definition: Predetermined price level to exit losing position

faq.question: What is the best time to invest in an IPO?
faq.answer: There's no universally 'best' time. Many experts suggest waiting 3-6 months after IPO for price stabilization and more financial data. The lockup period expiration (typically 180 days) often creates volatility. Research the company thoroughly and invest based on fundamentals, not hype.

faq.question: How do I evaluate if a stock is overvalued or undervalued?
faq.answer: Compare multiple metrics: P/E ratio vs industry average, PEG ratio (P/E divided by growth rate), Price-to-Book ratio, and DCF (Discounted Cash Flow) analysis. Also consider qualitative factors like competitive advantages, management quality, and industry trends.

faq.question: What's the difference between market cap and enterprise value?
faq.answer: Market Cap = Share Price × Shares Outstanding. Enterprise Value = Market Cap + Debt - Cash. EV gives a more complete picture of company value as it accounts for debt and cash, making it better for comparing companies with different capital structures.

faq.question: Should I invest in dividend stocks or growth stocks?
faq.answer: It depends on your goals. Dividend stocks provide regular income and lower volatility, suitable for income-focused or conservative investors. Growth stocks offer higher potential returns but more volatility, better for long-term capital appreciation. A balanced portfolio often includes both.

faq.question: How much of my portfolio should be in IPOs?
faq.answer: IPOs are higher risk. Most financial advisors recommend limiting IPO exposure to 5-10% of your portfolio. Prioritize established companies and diversification. Only invest in IPOs you've thoroughly researched and understand.
